moment_1.explanation: The first moment is the mean of data.
moment_1.citation:
@article{2020SciPy-NMeth,
  author  = {Virtanen, Pauli and Gommers, Ralf and Oliphant, Travis E. and
            Haberland, Matt and Reddy, Tyler and Cournapeau, David and

            Brett, Matthew and Wilson, Joshua and Millman, K. Jarrod and
            Mayorov, Nikolay and Nelson, Andrew R. J. and Jones, Eric and
            Kern, Robert and Larson, Eric and Carey, C J and
            Polat, {\.I}lhan and Feng, Yu and Moore, Eric W. and
            {VanderPlas}, Jake and Laxalde, Denis and Perktold, Josef and
            Cimrman, Robert and Henriksen, Ian and Quintero, E. A. and
            Harris, Charles R. and Archibald, Anne M. and
            Ribeiro, Ant{\^o}nio H. and Pedregosa, Fabian and
            {van Mulbregt}, Paul and {SciPy 1.0 Contributors}},
  title   = {{{SciPy} 1.0: Fundamental Algorithms for Scientific

  volume  = {17},
  pages   = {261--272},

}
  
@book{kokoska2000crc,
  title={CRC standard probability and statistics tables and formulae},
  author={Kokoska, Stephen and Zwillinger, Daniel},
  year={2000},
  publisher={Crc Press}

moment_2.explanation:
The second moment is the variance of data.
Variance describes the natural spread of data.

moment_3.explanation:
The third moment is the skewness of data.
Skewness refers to the asymmetry of data.
moment_3.citation:
